Read this sample answer to the writing task in the previous exercise and find the mistakes. There are 10. Click on them.
Writing Task 1

section.p: The table shows how the percentages of male and female smokers changed in Britain over more than three decades and compares trends for six socio-economic groups.Worryingly, smoking became less common for all groups between 1972 and 1999. However, it is clear that throughout the period there was a much higher proportion of smokers in certain socio-economic groups than others. As far as overall trends, the figures show a dramatic fall in the proportion of smokers for both sexes. For men the percentage more than halved over the period and for women it fell by almost a third. Furthermore, the gap between the proportion of men who smoked and women who smoked narrowed from 10 per cent in 1972 to about 2 per cent in 1999. Encouragingly, the table clearly shows that smoking remained more prevalent among certain socio-economic groups than others. In 1972, a third of professional men smoked compared to well over two-thirds of unskilled manual workers. As regards the former are concerned, the proportion of smokers approximately halved over the period. In comparison, the proportion of unskilled manual workers who smoked fell by exactly a third. To sum up, we can say that while smoking generally became less popular in Britain over the period, it became increasingly associated with the manual socio-economic groups.

p.font: Encouragingly: The fact that smoking became less common is good news.
Less positively: The fact that some groups are more likely to smoke can't be describe as 'encouraging'.
